llm_message:
P1. Title: "Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis on the Influence of Surgeon Specialization on Outcomes Following Appendicectomy in Children" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study is to assess the influence of surgeon specialization on outcomes following appendicectomy in children." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "An expanding body of evidence suggests that surgeon subspecialization affects outcomes; studies found that colorectal surgery subspecialization and orthopedic surgery subspecialization lead to improved results and that outcomes from a variety of cancers are improved with subspecialization." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to determine the influence of surgeon subspecialty on outcomes following appendicectomy in children." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligible studies were comparative and provided data on children who had appendicectomy while under the care of general or pediatric surgical teams." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "Two authors searched Medline and Embase to identify relevant studies." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No information provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two authors initially screened titles and abstracts and then full text manuscripts were evaluated." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors extracted data from eligible studies using an electronic spreadsheet." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: "Extracted data comprised details on the following variables: lead author, publication date, study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, outcomes reported, whether there was a specified primary endpoint, main results, numbers and characteristics of patients, surgical approach, rate of negative appendiceal histology, wound infections, intra-abdominal collections, readmissions, mortality, and length of stay." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Pooled risk ratios and pooled mean differences were used to evaluate the effect of treatment by general surgery units or pediatric surgery units on dichotomous and continuous outcomes, respectively." [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided [No]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "We identified 9 relevant studies involving 50,963 children who were managed by general surgery teams and 15,032 children who were managed by pediatric surgery teams." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Characteristics of the 9 included studies are shown in Table 1 and results from the studies are provided in Table 2." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "A normal appendix was removed in 4660/48,105 children treated by general surgery units and in 889/14,760 children treated by pediatric units." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided [No]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "We found that children who were managed by specialized pediatric surgery teams had lower rates of negative appendicectomy although mean length of stay was longer." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Our article is based upon a group of heterogeneous and mostly retrospective studies, and therefore there is little external validity." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "We wish to encourage future research through the use of large-scale prospective multicenter registries." [Yes]
P27. Funding: No information provided [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Pediatric incidental appendectomy: a systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "A detailed review was undertaken of the techniques, pathology, risks of appendectomy, utility of the appendix, and incidental appendectomy in the treatment of specific pediatric medical conditions." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The risks and benefits of incidental appendectomy during various operations in children have been debated for over a century, but need to be revisited in light of innovations in medical practice." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To review the available literature for techniques, pathology, risks of appendectomy, utility of the appendix, and IA in the treatment of specific pediatric medical conditions." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "A comprehensive literature search was performed, and retrieved results were reviewed for relevance to the topic." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A comprehensive literature search was performed using Ovid MEDLINE and Embase." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "The search identified studies comparing the risks of performing an incidental or prophylactic appendectomy versus leaving the appendix in place." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data was collected to index the type of study, specialty, year, location, number of patients, and primary outcomes of each study." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "From the initial 389 search results, 132 were selected as potentially relevant to our review." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Of these, 24 publications related to adult IA, 12 specifically to obstetrics and gynecology in adults, and 12 to pediatric surgery." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "In pediatric cases, approximately 11.6 % of incidentally removed appendices had abnormal pathologic findings." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Thoughtful consideration should be given to the individual pediatric patient’s co-morbid conditions before performing IA." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The decision whether to perform IA does not have a single simple answer and must consider the global condition of the individual patient." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "The decision to perform IA needs to be carefully weighed in regards to the procedure to be performed, the patients’ medical history, and the likelihood of requiring the appendix for future use." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The purpose of this review was to determine the place of MIA in children." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) is the criterion standard for removal of small adrenal tumors in adults." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "we attempted to answer the following questions: Is MIA superior to open adrenalectomy (OA)? What is the best approach (transperitoneal or retroperitoneal)? What are the pediatric indications for MIA?" [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "focusing on the technique and indications" [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "The authors conducted a systematic review of the pediatric and adult literature about MIA" [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: Not reported [No]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: Not reported [No]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The authors conducted a systematic review of the pediatric and adult literature about MIA" [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy appears superior to open adrenalectomy for small tumors." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy is promising for removal of small adrenal tumors." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: Not reported [No]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy is potentially superior to OA for the removal of noninvasive tumors with low morbidity rates." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "An updated meta-analysis of laparoscopic versus open pyeloplasty for ureteropelvic junction obstruction in children" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings. [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known. [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS). [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration information. [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: The methods specify study characteristics (PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale. [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: The methods describe all information sources used in the search and the date last searched. [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: The methods present the full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used. [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: The methods state the process for selecting studies. [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators. [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: No information is provided about the variables for which data were sought. [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information is provided about the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies. [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: The methods state the principal summary measures. [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: The results give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage. [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: The results present characteristics for which data were extracted and provide the citations. [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information is provided about the risk of bias of each study. [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: The results present simple summary data for each intervention group. [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable, as there is no additional analysis. [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome. [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: The discussion discusses limitations at study and outcome level, and at review-level. [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research. [Yes]
P27. Funding: The funding sources for the systematic review and other support are described. [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Flexible ureteroscopy and lasertripsy (FURSL) for paediatric renal calculi: Results from a systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: No abstract or structured summary provided [No]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "To understand the role, safety and efficacy of flexible ureterorenoscopy and lasertripsy (FURSL) for paediatric renal stones." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The objective of the present systematic review of the literature was to investigate the role of flexible ureterorenoscopy and lasertripsy (FURSL) in the management of renal calculi in the paediatric population and to look at its efficacy and safety." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All English language articles reporting on a minimum of five patients ≤18-years old, treated with flexible ureteroscopy and lasertripsy for stone disease were included." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "The search involved finding relevant studies from MEDLINE, EMBASE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, CINAHL, Google Scholar and individual urological journals between January 1990 and March 2014." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No information provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: No information provided [No]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: No information provided [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: No information provided [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: No information provided [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of six studies (282 patients) were reported" [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The mean age of all the study populations was 7.3 years (range 0.25–17 years)" [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The mean stone-free rate across the three studies was 85.5% (range 58.0–93.0%)" [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The present systematic review highlights that FURSL can be used even for stones in lower pole locations, for stones up to 30 mm, and in children from the age of three months." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The first limitation is that all of the reviewed studies were retrospective studies and the results were not recorded in a uniform manner to allow the data to be meta-analysed. Second, the numbers involved in these studies were small and this may skew the results, as the authors may be reporting on their initial experiences." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "The present review shows that, despite the small numbers studied, FURSL in the management of renal calculi in the paediatric population is an effective and safe procedure in high-volume centres." [Yes]
P27. Funding: No information provided [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Surgical versus conservative management of congenital pulmonary airway malformation in children: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing elective resection versus expectant management."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and results.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal management of infants born with asymptomatic congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is controversial."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "Our objective was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis of all published literature comparing the postoperative outcomes associated with elective surgery (while asymptomatic) versus those following surgery as part of expectant management (i.e., performing surgery only upon the development of symptoms) in children born with asymptomatic CPAM lesions."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We conducted an electronic literature search of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and PubMed in January 2015."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We conducted an electronic literature search of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL, and PubMed in January 2015."
[Yes] All information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "We used the search terms (“asymptomatic” AND “congenital” AND “cystic” AND “adenomatoid malformation”) OR (“lung” AND “lesion”) AND (“management” OR “treatment” OR “therapy.”)"
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy for at least one database is presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two independent reviewers conducted all article screening; where consensus on an article could not be reached, a third reviewer was consulted."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is stated.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "One reviewer extracted all data from the included studies, and another checked it for accuracy and completeness."
[Yes] The method of data extraction from reports is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "We extracted the following data exclusively on patients who were asymptomatic at birth: number of patients undergoing elective surgery, number undergoing surgery as part of expectant management (after symptom development), age at symptom development if applicable, postoperative complications, mortalities, and total length of postoperative hospital stay, as well as number of patients successfully managed conservatively at the end of follow-up, and length of follow-up for these patients."
[Yes] The variables for which data were sought are listed and defined.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided.
[No] There is no mention of methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "We conducted our meta-analyses using Review Manager 5.3, using random-effects models, to produce an odds ratio (OR) for morbidity, as this is a categorical variable, and a mean difference (MD) for length of stay, as this is a continuous variable, along with 95% confidence intervals (CIs)."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Our electronic search yielded 342 studies. After applying our exclusion criteria to titles and abstracts, 63 studies remained. Full-text review resulted in eight of these studies being included, while an additional one was identified from hand-searching the reference sections of included articles; nine studies were ultimately included."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Our electronic search yielded 342 studies. After applying our exclusion criteria to titles and abstracts, 63 studies remained. Full-text review resulted in eight of these studies being included, while an additional one was identified from hand-searching the reference sections of included articles; nine studies were ultimately included."
[Yes] Characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided.
[No] There is no presentation of data on risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Out of 168 patients, 70 underwent surgery before symptoms developed with seven experiencing postoperative complications (10.0%); 63 developed symptoms while being managed expectantly and subsequently underwent surgery with 20 complications (31.8%)."
[Yes] Results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Based on our results, we recommend elective resection of asymptomatic CPAM lesions, rather than expectant management."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Our results should be interpreted with caution owing to the nature of the included studies (in that all but one were retrospective)."
[Yes] Limitations are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Based on our results, we recommend elective resection of asymptomatic CPAM lesions, rather than expectant management."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results is provided.

P27. Funding: "The University of Ottawa Summer Studentship program provided financial support for this project."
[Yes] Sources of funding for the systematic review are described.

P1. Title: "Paediatric sutureless circumcision: a systematic literature review"
1. Quote: "Paediatric sutureless circumcision: a systematic literature review"
2. Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic literature review.
3. Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Circumcision can be undertaken using a variety of techniques. For the technique to be successful, it should be easy to perform, avoid excessive haemorrhage and achieve a good cosmetic and functional result with minimal postoperative care. Naturally, there are differences between circumcision in the paediatric and adult populations and here we review the literature on recent advances that have been made in paediatric circumcision and the use of a sutureless technique with tissue glue for wound approximation."
1. Quote: "Circumcision can be undertaken using a variety of techniques. For the technique to be successful, it should be easy to perform, avoid excessive haemorrhage and achieve a good cosmetic and functional result with minimal postoperative care. Naturally, there are differences between circumcision in the paediatric and adult populations and here we review the literature on recent advances that have been made in paediatric circumcision and the use of a sutureless technique with tissue glue for wound approximation."
2. Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and the topic of the review.
3. Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Circumcision is one of the most commonly performed operations [1], with various recognised techniques. Procedures include the Plastibell with ligature [2] and excision with or without suturing. Absorbable sutures have traditionally been used to approximate the skin edges. The disadvantage of this method of wound approximation, however, is in the postoperative appearance, with the formation of small granulomata and the persistence of stitch marks along suture line [3]."

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Neonatal Endosurgical Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To compare outcomes of open and endosurgical neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) repairs."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Historically a surgical emergency, neonatal CDH repair is now deferred pending stabilization of characteristically labile cardiopulmonary physiology."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare outcomes of open and endosurgical neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) repairs."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies were eligible for inclusion in the review and meta-analysis if they directly compared open and endosurgical CDH repair in the newborn infant and included outcome data regarding survival, CDH recurrence, prosthetic patch use, and operative time."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Trials databases for studies comparing open with endosurgical CDH repair."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two independent reviewers reviewed all studies in abstract form. Exclusions were only made at this point if it was absolutely clear that the above criteria were met."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data were extracted from the original study report or obtained directly from the corresponding author."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "The following demographic data was sought for each group: proportion of male sex, proportion with left-sided CDH, mean birth weight, mean gestational age, APGAR score at 1 minute, proportion requiring ECMO, and proportion with significant associated anomalies."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "The primary outcome measure was survival to discharge from hospital. The secondary outcome measures were: CDH recurrence rate, proportion undergoing prosthetic patching, and operative time."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The electronic search identified a total of 292 studies. Exclusions were made as detailed in the flow chart."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The 3 included studies compare series of neonatal thoracoscopic and open CDH repairs performed at the same institutions."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "All eligible studies compare thoracoscopic versus open CDH repair: we were therefore unable to compare laparoscopic CDH repair and open surgery in this meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Meta-analysis reveals that recurrence was higher and operative time longer in the endosurgical group. Survival and patch usage were not different between open and endosurgical groups."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This meta-analysis of methodologically limited comparative studies indicates neonatal thoracoscopic CDH repair has increased recurrence risk and operative time compared with open repair: although survival and patch usage appear comparable, such similarities may be subject to type 2 error as well as biases."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The analyzed studies report small numbers of cases and are therefore vulnerable to type 2 error (failure to detect a real difference)."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Better quality evidence is therefore required. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses frequently conclude with calls for more randomized controlled trials (RCTs). In contrast, we call for prospective, comprehensive, multi-institutional registry data on neonatal endosurgical CDH repair."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

P1. Title: "Management of pediatric blunt renal trauma: A systematic review" - [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This study aimed to review current practices in pediatric blunt renal trauma management and to highlight current practices in conservative protocols, success rates of conservative management strategies, as well as short- and long-term outcomes of blunt renal trauma management." - [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Blunt trauma remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in the pediatric population. The use of conservative management for blunt renal trauma is widely accepted in adult trauma literature and is now increasingly accepted for use in the pediatric patient population." - [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This study aimed to review current practices in pediatric blunt renal trauma management and to highlight current practices in conservative protocols, success rates of conservative management strategies, as well as short- and long-term outcomes of blunt renal trauma management." - [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported - [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria were (1) original research articles regarding management of pediatric blunt renal trauma, (2) involvement of cases of high-grade renal (Grades IV and V) trauma, and (3) more than one patient presented per study. Literature reviews and meta-analyses were excluded." - [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A search of all original research studies was conducted using PubMed, Ovid, and the Cochrane Library." - [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: "The following search was performed in PubMed: (Renal or Kidney) AND (Pediatric or Children) AND Trauma AND Management." - [Yes]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Titles and abstracts (n = 308) were screened to identify scientific articles reporting original research findings. A total of 32 articles met the selection criteria and were included in the review." - [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Treatment protocols, intervention type, outcome measures including percent success of conservative protocols, and renal salvage rates were recorded." - [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported - [NA]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Bias was assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias assessment tool." - [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Renal salvage rates were recorded." - [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses) - [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 32 articles met the selection criteria and were included in the review." - [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Characteristics of Studies Included in the Review" - [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported - [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Treatment protocols, intervention type, outcome measures including percent success of conservative protocols, and renal salvage rates were recorded." - [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses) - [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The literature supports application of conservative management protocols to high-grade blunt pediatric renal trauma." - [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The review was limited by the retrospective nature of the studies included and the relatively small sample size because of the infrequency with which pediatric renal trauma occurs." - [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Based on the analysis of the available literature, we recommend implementation of conservative management protocols to treat high-grade blunt pediatric renal trauma." - [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Lymphatic Sparing Versus Lymphatic Non-Sparing Laparoscopic Varicocelectomy in Children and Adolescents: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
2. The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to explore the true efficacy and potential advantages of lymphatic sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LSV) over lymphatic non-sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LNSV) in children and adolescents."
3. The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and study eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Varicocele, an abnormal tortuosity and dilatation of the testicular vein within the spermatic cord, first develops in childhood or early adolescence. The prevalence of varicocele in adolescent boys is estimated to be 11–15%. It has been established that adolescent varicocele is associated with growth retardation of the ipsilateral testicle and impaired testicular function, which is correlated to the duration of the varicocele. Although some studies have challenged the role varicocele plays in infertility, many studies have stated that varicocele is associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal parameters contributing to male infertility. Surgical management of adolescent varicocele has been advocated to preserve future fertility. The earlier the patient undergoes varicocele repair, the more likely the testis will recover from a varicocele-induced injury. Currently, several techniques are successfully used for varicocelectomy including open surgical ligation via a subinguinal, inguinal or retroperitoneal approach, and microsurgical and laparoscopic procedures. However, the efficacy of surgical procedures and the outcomes in boys and young adolescents remains unclear."
4. The rationale for the review is clearly described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study was to explore the true efficacy and potential advantages of lymphatic sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LSV) over lymphatic non-sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LNSV) in children and adolescents."
5. The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not applicable (no mention of a review protocol or registration number).
[NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria included all available studies comparing LSV with LNSV for varicocele repair in children and adolescents."
6. The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A search was made for all studies published up until 31 August 2010 using the terms “lymphatic sparing varicocelectomy”, “laparoscopy”, “adolescent” and “children” in the Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases."
7. All information sources used in the search are described.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "A search was made for all studies published up until 31 August 2010 using the terms “lymphatic sparing varicocelectomy”, “laparoscopy”, “adolescent” and “children” in the Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases."
8. The full electronic search strategy for at least one database is presented.
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Eligibility criteria included all available studies comparing LSV with LNSV for varicocele repair in children and adolescents."
9. The process for selecting studies is stated.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "3 reviewers independently assessed the selected studies, and extracted and tabulated data from each article using a predefined data extraction form."
10. The method of data extraction from reports is described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Data for the following factors were considered: first author, publication date, study methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, definition of complications, and outcome measures."
11. The variables for which data were sought are listed and defined.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers, who independently assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies."
12. The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed using odds ratios (ORs) for dichotomous variables."
13. The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no assessment of risk of bias across studies).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Out of 127 studies, 2 RCTs and 4 OCSs were eligible for inclusion."
14. The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "A summary of the studies’ methodology, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes is provided."
15. Characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers, who independently assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies."
16. Data on risk of bias of each study are presented.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "For all outcomes considered, present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
17. Simple summary data and effect estimates with confidence intervals are presented for each study.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no assessment of risk of bias across studies).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the lymphatic sparing laparoscopic approach is associated with a lower incidence of hydrocele formation, supporting the belief that lymphatic occlusion is the main cause of hydrocele formation after varicocelectomy."
18. The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Due to a potential publishing bias, a series of RCTs are still necessary to explore the efficacy of LSV in the management of varicocele in children and adolescents."
19. Limitations at study and outcome level, as well as at review-level, are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the lymphatic sparing laparoscopic approach is associated with a lower incidence of hydrocele formation, with similar recurrence and catch-up growth rates as LNSV."
20. A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China, Program for New Century Excellent Talents in the University of China, the Scientific Research Foundation for Returned Overseas Chinese Scholars, State Education Ministry, and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities."
21. Sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are described.
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
"systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
"Background...Design...Data sources...Study selection...Data extraction...Results...Conclusion"
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
"Biliary atresia (BA) is one of the most common reasons for portoenterostomy in pediatric surgery...The etiology of BA remains unknown...Since first reported by Kasai and Suzuki in 1959, portoenterostomy (PE) remains the mainstay of treating BA."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
"we performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) versus open portoenterostomy (OPE) for the treatment of biliary atresia (BA)."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
No information provided.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
"For inclusion in this meta-analysis, the studies had to meet the following criteria: (1) be a cohort study comparing laparoscopic technique and open technique in BA patients undergoing portoenterostomy; (2) include at least one interest datum for analysis—hospital stay, operative time, blood loss, complications, early clearance of jaundice, the rate of long-term survival with native liver; (3) clearly document technique as ‘‘laparoscopic’’ or ‘‘open’’; (4) clearly document indications for portoenterostomy with biliary atresia; (5) be published as a full paper in a journal, not as meeting abstract or review."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
"We conducted a systematic search of the online databases, including Medline, Ovid, Elsevier, Google Scholar Embase, Cohrane library, for studies published between 1995 and 2014 with no limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
No information provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
"The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
"Two independent authors (QG and ZZ) using a predefined meta-analysis form extracted relevant data from each study which resulted in high and satisfactory interobserver agreement."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
"The following data were the outcomes of interest that extracted from each included study: first author, publication year, country, study design, number of patients who underwent LPE or OPE, characteristics of the study population, and end point data (operative times, hospital stay times, rate of conversion from LPE to OPE, re-operation rates, and complications about surgery including: intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice, cholangitis and variceal bleeding."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
No information provided.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
"For categorical variables data, statistical analysis was performed using the odds ratio (OR) as the statistic summary. This odds ratio represents the odds of an adverse event occurring in the LPE group compared with the OPE group. Statistical analysis for continuous variables was performed using the mean difference (MD) and as the summary statistic."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
No information provided.
[NA]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
No information provided.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
No information provided.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
"The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
"The characteristics of these 11 studies are listed in Table 1."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
No information provided.
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
"The main data for meta-analysis are summarized below and in Table 2."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
No information provided.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
No information provided.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
No information provided.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
"The results of our meta-analysis suggested that compared with OPE, LPEs were considered to be a poor treatment for BA in long-term outcomes with low 2-year survival of native liver, although LPEs performed well in short-term outcomes in the form of intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice and cholangitis."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
"There are limitations to this review which must be considered...First, there have only been a small number of studies comparing LPE with OPE in the treatment of biliary atresia, with a lack of randomized trials...Second, the sample size of some selected studies is small so that the statistical power to detect the difference in the outcomes is limited...Third, although most of the comparative cohort studies seem to be robust, risk of selection bias still existed...Fourth, marked heterogeneity for several meta-analysis, short follow-up time in some included studies, and the potentially existed significant risk of publication bias may more or less affect the accuracy of the results...Fifth, the other limitation is the length of follow-up."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
"Based on the evidence, we make cautious conclusions that laparoscopic portoenterostomy could not replace open portoenterostomy and open Kasai operation remains the ‘gold standard’ for the treatment of biliary atresia."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
"We thank those authors who provided us with the full text and the relevant data from their studies."
[Yes]

[Yes]

"we performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) versus open portoenterostomy (OPE) for the treatment of biliary atresia (BA)."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
No information provided.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
"For inclusion in this meta-analysis, the studies had to meet the following criteria: (1) be a cohort study comparing laparoscopic technique and open technique in BA patients undergoing portoenterostomy; (2) include at least one interest datum for analysis—hospital stay, operative time, blood loss, complications, early clearance of jaundice, the rate of long-term survival with native liver; (3) clearly document technique as ‘‘laparoscopic’’ or ‘‘open’’; (4) clearly document indications for portoenterostomy with biliary atresia; (5) be published as a full paper in a journal, not as meeting abstract or review."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
"We conducted a systematic search of the online databases, including Medline, Ovid, Elsevier, Google Scholar Embase, Cohrane library, for studies published between 1995 and 2014 with no limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
No information provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
"The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
"Two independent authors (QG and ZZ) using a predefined meta-analysis form extracted relevant data from each study which resulted in high and satisfactory interobserver agreement."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
"The following data were the outcomes of interest that extracted from each included study: first author, publication year, country, study design, number of patients who underwent LPE or OPE, characteristics of the study population, and end point data (operative times, hospital stay times, rate of conversion from LPE to OPE, re-operation rates, and complications about surgery including: intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice, cholangitis and variceal bleeding."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
No information provided.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
"For categorical variables data, statistical analysis was performed using the odds ratio (OR) as the statistic summary. This odds ratio represents the odds of an adverse event occurring in the LPE group compared with the OPE group. Statistical analysis for continuous variables was performed using the mean difference (MD) and as the summary statistic."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
No information provided.
[NA]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
No information provided.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
No information provided.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
"The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
"The characteristics of these 11 studies are listed in Table 1."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
No information provided.
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
"The main data for meta-analysis are summarized below and in Table 2."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
No information provided.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
No information provided.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
No information provided.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
"The results of our meta-analysis suggested that compared with OPE, LPEs were considered to be a poor treatment for BA in long-term outcomes with low 2-year survival of native liver, although LPEs performed well in short-term outcomes in the form of intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice and cholangitis."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
"There are limitations to this review which must be considered...First, there have only been a small number of studies comparing LPE with OPE in the treatment of biliary atresia, with a lack of randomized trials...Second, the sample size of some selected studies is small so that the statistical power to detect the difference in the outcomes is limited...Third, although most of the comparative cohort studies seem to be robust, risk of selection bias still existed...Fourth, marked heterogeneity for several meta-analysis, short follow-up time in some included studies, and the potentially existed significant risk of publication bias may more or less affect the accuracy of the results...Fifth, the other limitation is the length of follow-up."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
"Based on the evidence, we make cautious conclusions that laparoscopic portoenterostomy could not replace open portoenterostomy and open Kasai operation remains the ‘gold standard’ for the treatment of biliary atresia."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
"We thank those authors who provided us with the full text and the relevant data from their studies."
[Yes]

P1. Title: "Does Aggressive Surgical Resection Improve Survival in Advanced Stage 3 and 4 Neuroblastoma? A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "A systematic review and meta-analysis is reported to address robust evidence for curative 'gross total tumor resection' (GTR) in Stage 3 and Stage 4 neuroblastoma."

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Hepaticoduodenostomy versus hepaticojejunostomy after resection of choledochal cyst: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Background: Excision has been established as a standard management practice for choledochal cysts in the last few decades. The two most commonly performed methods of reconstruction after excision are hepaticoduodenostomy (HD) and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (HJ), of which the HJ is favored by most surgeons. Evidence concerning the optimal method of reconstruction is, however, sparse. Methods: Studies comparing outcomes from HD and HJ after choledochal cyst excision were identified by searching Medline, Ovid, Search Medica, Elsevier Clinicalkey, Google Scholar and Cochrane library. Suitable studies were chosen and data extracted for meta-analysis. Results: Six retrospective studies were included in this meta-analysis, comprising a total of 679 patients, 412 of whom (60.7%) underwent HD, and the remainder, 267(39.3%) underwent HJ. Although, HD group had slightly shorter hospital stay (MD: 0.30; 95% CI: −0.22–0.39; P < 0.00001) it showed a higher incidence of postoperative reflux/gastritis (OR: 0.08; 95% CI: − 0.02–0.39; P = 0.002). However, the other outcomes such as bile leak, cholangitis, anastomotic stricture, bleeding, operative time, reoperation rate and adhesive intestinal obstruction did not differ between HD and HJ groups. Conclusions: HD shows higher postoperative reflux/gastritis than HJ but a shorter hospital stay. There are few good-quality studies that compare the outcomes from HD and HJ, meaning that caution should be exercised in the generalization of the results of this meta-analysis, which suggests HD to be comparable with HJ in terms of other complications, operative benefits and outcomes."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Excision has been established as a standard management practice for choledochal cysts in the last few decades. The two most commonly performed methods of reconstruction after excision are hepaticoduodenostomy (HD) and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (HJ), of which the HJ is favored by most surgeons. Evidence concerning the optimal method of reconstruction is, however, sparse."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare the clinical outcomes of HD and HJ, we performed a systematic review and comprehensive meta-analysis from indexed published literature."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies comparing outcomes from HD and HJ after choledochal cyst excision were identified by searching Medline, Ovid, Search Medica, Elsevier Clinicalkey, Google Scholar and Cochrane library."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "Studies comparing outcomes from HD and HJ after choledochal cyst excision were identified by searching Medline, Ovid, Search Medica, Elsevier Clinicalkey, Google Scholar and Cochrane library."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "A Medline, Ovid, Search Medica, Elsevier ClinicalKey, Google Scholar and the Cochrane library search was performed on all studies published between 1950 and 2012 reporting on comparison of HD and HJ for children undergoing excision of extra-hepatic biliary tree for choledochal cysts."
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Three reviewers (SKN, KLN and CY) independently assessed selected studies, extracted and tabulated data from each article: first author, year of publication, study design, follow up period, mean age and number of subjects operated on with each technique, and end point data (operative times, length of postoperative hospital stay, re-operation rates and postoperative complications including bile leak, adhesive intestinal obstruction, cholangitis, reflux/gastritis and anastomotic stricture)."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Three reviewers (SKN, KLN and CY) independently assessed selected studies, extracted and tabulated data from each article: first author, year of publication, study design, follow up period, mean age and number of subjects operated on with each technique, and end point data (operative times, length of postoperative hospital stay, re-operation rates and postoperative complications including bile leak, adhesive intestinal obstruction, cholangitis, reflux/gastritis and anastomotic stricture)."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Three reviewers (SKN, KLN and CY) independently assessed selected studies, extracted and tabulated data from each article: first author, year of publication, study design, follow up period, mean age and number of subjects operated on with each technique, and end point data (operative times, length of postoperative hospital stay, re-operation rates and postoperative complications including bile leak, adhesive intestinal obstruction, cholangitis, reflux/gastritis and anastomotic stricture)."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method and pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No information provided.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No additional analyses performed.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Six retrospective studies were included in this meta-analysis, comprising a total of 679 patients, 412 of whom (60.7%) underwent HD, and the remainder, 267(39.3%) underwent HJ."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The characteristics of these studies are demonstrated in Table 1."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Although, HD group had slightly shorter hospital stay (MD: 0.30; 95% CI: −0.22–0.39; P < 0.00001) it showed a higher incidence of postoperative reflux/gastritis (OR: 0.08; 95% CI: − 0.02–0.39; P = 0.002). However, the other outcomes such as bile leak, cholangitis, anastomotic stricture, bleeding, operative time, reoperation rate and adhesive intestinal obstruction did not differ between HD and HJ groups."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results:
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies:
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis:
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our meta-analysis suggests that the HD is comparable to conventional HJ in most postoperative outcomes except a higher rate of gastric reflux."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "There are few good-quality studies that compare the outcomes from HD and HJ, meaning that caution should be exercised in the generalization of the results of this meta-analysis, which suggests HD to be comparable with HJ in terms of other complications, operative benefits and outcomes."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Based on the evidence of this study, HD as a method of reconstruction after excision of a choledochal cyst is a suitable alternative to HJ."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: No information provided.
[No]

P1. Title: "Comparison of the Nuss and the Ravitch procedure for pectus excavatum repair: a meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Our objective was to compare the Nuss procedure to the Ravitch procedure using systematic review and meta-analysis methodology."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "As more pediatric centers add the Nuss procedure to their surgical armamentarium, data indicating complication rates and surgical outcome are becoming available."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "Our objective was to compare both the Nuss and the Ravitch procedure using systematic review and meta-analysis methodology."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "To be selected, a study had to be designed to evaluate the Nuss vs the Ravitch procedure for the treatment of pectus excavatum and provide relevant and interpretable data."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "All publications describing both surgical procedures for pectus excavatum were sought from the Cochrane Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) database."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Three authors independently assessed all published articles identified as potentially relevant by the literature search for inclusion in the review."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors independently extracted data from the retrieved articles."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Odds ratios (OR) and weighted mean differences (WMDs) with 95% confidence intervals are presented."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Nine prospective and retrospective studies were identified and were included in this study."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All data extracted from the 9 studies are summarized in Table 1."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis performed).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses performed).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our results suggest no differences between the Nuss procedure vs the Ravitch procedure with respect to overall complications, length of hospital stay, and time to ambulation."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The evaluation and management of postoperative pain and patient satisfaction were not standardized, thus making it impossible to calculate a pooled estimate."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Both approaches are acceptable."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Is laparoscopy still needed in blunt abdominal trauma?" - [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study is to assess the role of laparoscopy in the diagnosis and therapy of BAT." - [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Laparoscopy is not as frequently applied as anticipated at the beginning of laparoscopic revolution in the ’90s." - [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study is to assess the role of laparoscopy in the diagnosis and therapy of BAT." - [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported - [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All articles referring to pediatric surgery, penetrating trauma, nontraumatic abdominal emergencies, iatrogenic injury were excluded." - [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A comprehensive literature search was performed on the U.S. National Library of Medicine site in Medline and PubMed from 1 Ian 2000 to 31 Dec 2007 using keywords such as 'laparoscopy and blunt abdominal trauma'." - [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported - [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "66 articles were reviewed, which included 22 case studies, 27 case reports, 17 reviews and 2 guidelines." - [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported - [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported - [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported - [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported - [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "66 articles were reviewed, which included 22 case studies, 27 case reports, 17 reviews and 2 guidelines." - [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: Not reported - [No]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported - [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "343 patients with BAT were approached using laparoscopy, with one therapeutic laparoscopy possible in 48,98% patients (168/343), and 14,87% in need of conversion (51/343)." - [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Laparoscopy is still an effective and safe diagnostic and therapeutic tool, which can significantly reduce the number of unnecessary laparotomies." - [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The main limitations attributed to laparoscopy were the lack of adequate equipment and trained medical personnel, the issue of general anesthesia, and the fact that it is invasive, expensive, and does not allow a proper visualization of hollow organ injuries." - [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "In carefully selected cases with BAT, laparoscopy is still an effective and safe diagnostic and therapeutic tool." - [Yes]
P27. Funding: "The author does not have any conflict of interest." - [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Neophalloplasty in boys with aphallia: A systematic review" - [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature on neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives and clinical outcome." - [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Aphallia is a rare penile congenital abnormality. The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature on neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives and clinical outcome." - [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this systematic review was to assess all available literature on neophalloplasty in infancy with an interest in technical alternatives and clinical outcome." - [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported - [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We performed a Pubmed search using the terms: neophalloplasty, neophallus, and phalloplasty, and selected articles that presented technical alternatives for penile construction in cases of penile dysgenesis, especially aphallia in children and/or adolescents." - [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We performed a Pubmed search using the terms: neophalloplasty, neophallus, and phalloplasty, and selected articles that presented technical alternatives for penile construction in cases of penile dysgenesis, especially aphallia in children and/or adolescents." - [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported - [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "We performed a Pubmed search using the terms: neophalloplasty, neophallus, and phalloplasty, and selected articles that presented technical alternatives for penile construction in cases of penile dysgenesis, especially aphallia in children and/or adolescents." - [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported - [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported - [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported - [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported - [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 319 articles were identified in the initial search. Among the different techniques presented in 19 papers collected, we categorized reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques." - [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Among the different techniques presented in the 19 papers collected initially, we were able to assemble reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques." - [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported - [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Among the different techniques presented in the 19 papers collected, we categorized reconstructive procedures into two groups: microsurgical and non-microsurgical techniques." - [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Taking recent literature into account, it seems rational that neophalloplasty be regarded as the preferred strategy for boys born with aphallia." - [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Studies reporting on late clinical presentation post puberty, specifically in regards to sexual development-pleasure and quality of life, are still lacking." - [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "As a personal input, based on this review and considering our personal experience, we still believe that flap techniques should be the first choice when treating a child with penile agenesis." - [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported - [No]

In summary, out of the 27 PRISMA items:
- 14 items were reported
- 10 items were not reported
- 3 items were not applicable
