P1. Title: "Surgical approaches for neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of endoscopic surgery (ES) for neonatal CDH."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and results.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The optimal surgical approach for neonatal congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) remains unclear."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the introduction.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of endoscopic surgery (ES) for neonatal CDH."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies that compared surgical approaches for neonatal CDH were selected."
[Yes] The study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic literature search was conducted using MEDLINE and the Cochrane Library."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "The articles were screened according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) flow chart."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy is not provided, but the use of the PRISMA flow chart is mentioned.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is not explicitly stated, but it can be inferred that studies were screened and included in the systematic review.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two individual authors extracted data from each selected study."
[Yes] The method of data extraction is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "The following items were collected: (1) authors’ names and year of publication, (2) title of the published study, (3) journal in which the study was published, (4) country and year of the study, (5) whether the study was single-center or multicenter, (6) whether the study had a prospective or retrospective design, (7) testing sample size, (8) patient age, (9) whether consecutive patients were included, (10) surgical approaches in both arms of the trial, (11) method of assigning patients to the two groups, (12) number of patients receiving each surgical approach, (13) number of patients who failed the allocated treatment (conversion to OS), (14) postoperative follow-up period, (15) number of postoperative deaths, and (16) number of patients who developed recurrence."
[Yes] The data items for which data were sought are listed and defined.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "As assessed on the GRADE scale, the quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes."
[Yes] The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Risk ratios (RRs) and 95 % confidential intervals (CIs) were determined using RevMan 5.3 software."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: "Of 264 search results, 226 studies were excluded based on titles and abstracts. After screening the remaining 38 studies based on their full texts, 14 studies were included in the qualitative synthesis."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The eight observational studies were included in a quantitative synthesis."
[Yes] The characteristics of the included studies are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "As assessed on the GRADE scale, the quality of evidence was very low for all outcomes."
[Yes] Data on risk of bias of each study are presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The ES group showed both a significantly lower mortality rate and a significantly higher recurrence rate compared to the OS group."
[Yes] The results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Although the evidence was insufficient, ES was clearly associated with more recurrence than was OS."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "There was very serious risk of bias due to inappropriate patient selection, unequal follow-up durations, and the absence of controlling for confounding."
[Yes] The limitations of the review are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "ES should not be the routine treatment for every neonate. It is crucially important to select suitable cases for ES."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "This work was supported by a grant from the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review are described.

Overall, 24 out of 27 PRISMA items were reported in the full text.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Laparoscopic assistance for primary transanal pull-through in Hirschsprung's disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Objective To compare outcomes following totally transanal endorectal pull-through (TTERPT) versus pull-through with any form of laparoscopic assistance (LAPT) for infants with uncomplicated Hirschsprung's disease."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Since the first description of Harald Hirschsprung's eponymous condition in 1889, there has been ongoing debate regarding the optimal surgical approach."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the introduction.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to compare outcomes for infants with Hirschsprung's disease undergoing a TTERPT procedure with those undergoing a laparoscopically assisted transanal pull-through (LAPT)."
[Yes] The objectives of the study are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: "A study protocol outlining the search strategy, outcomes, and methods of data extraction and statistical analysis was designed and prospectively registered with the Prospero database (CRD42013005698)."
[Yes] The existence of a study protocol and its registration information is provided.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Study inclusion and exclusion criteria are summarised in table 1."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched all publications from 1 January 1998 to 1 January 2014 from EMBASE, MEDLINE and Cochrane library databases using the search strategy detailed in online supplementary appendix I."
[Yes] All information sources used in the search are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "We searched all publications from 1 January 1998 to 1 January 2014 from EMBASE, MEDLINE and Cochrane library databases using the search strategy detailed in online supplementary appendix I."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy for at least one database is presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Titles and abstracts of potentially relevant papers were screened by two independent authors (DT and BA). The full texts of all identified studies were assessed against the criteria in table 1 by the two independent authors (DT and BA), and study reference lists were hand searched for potentially relevant studies."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Data were extracted by the two independent authors (DT and BA) using a predesigned proforma."
[Yes] The method of data extraction from reports is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "Data were collected regarding: age at gestation, diagnosis and surgery, level of anal dissection, length of mucosal cuff, length and location of aganglionosis, and any congenital abnormalities."
[Yes] The variables for which data were sought are listed and defined.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Study quality was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for case–control and cohort studies."
[Yes] The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Continuous data were analysed using an inverse variance model to produce a mean difference. Dichotomous variables were analysed using a Mantel-Haenszel model to produce ORs."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 2107 records were screened, of which 41 studies potentially met the eligibility criteria."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Four hundred and five patients were included in the meta-analysis; 159 underwent a LAPT and 248 underwent a TTERPT."
[Yes] The characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "Study quality was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for cohort studies. Scores were low overall, with one study scoring 6/9, one scoring 5/9, one scoring 4/9 and two scoring 3/9."
[Yes] Data on risk of bias of each study are presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "There were no significant differences identified between TTERPT and LAPT for incidence of postoperative enterocolitis, faecal incontinence, or constipation."
[Yes] The results of each individual study are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: [NA] Not applicable, as there is no additional analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This meta-analysis did not find any evidence to suggest a higher rate of enterocolitis, incontinence or constipation following TTERPT compared with LAPT."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The main limitations of this study include limited statistical power as we identified only five eligible studies, the generally low quality of the studies, heterogeneity with respect to outcome assessment, and limited long-term follow-up."
[Yes] The limitations of the study are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Further long-term comparative studies and multicentre data pooling are needed to determine whether a purely transanal approach offers any advantages over a laparoscopically assisted approach to rectosigmoid Hirschsprung's disease."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "MK is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship."
[Yes] The sources of funding for the systematic review are described.

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
"Systematic review" is mentioned in the title. [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions. [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known. [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design. [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration information. [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
The methods specify the study characteristics (e.g., PICOS) used as criteria for eligibility, but do not mention report characteristics or provide a rationale. [Partial]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
The methods describe the information sources (CENTRAL, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL) used in the search, but do not mention the dates of coverage or contact with study authors. [Partial]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
The methods do not present the full electronic search strategy. [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
The methods state the process for selecting studies, including screening and eligibility, but do not mention inclusion in the systematic review or meta-analysis. [Partial]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
The methods do not describe the method of data extraction or any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators. [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
The methods do not list and define all variables for which data were sought or mention any assumptions and simplifications made. [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
The methods do not describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies or how this information is to be used in any data synthesis. [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
The methods do not state the principal summary measures. [No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
Not applicable, as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies. [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
Not applicable, as there are no additional analyses. [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
The results give the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, but do not provide reasons for exclusions or a flow diagram. [Partial]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
The results present characteristics for each study, including study size, PICOS, and follow-up period, and provide the citations. [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
The results do not present data on risk of bias within studies or any outcome level assessment. [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
The results present simple summary data for each intervention group, but do not provide effect estimates, confidence intervals, or a forest plot. [Partial]

Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis. [NA]

Not applicable, as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies. [NA]

Not applicable, as there are no additional analyses. [NA]

The discussion summarizes the main findings, but does not consider the strength of evidence for each main outcome or their relevance to key groups. [Partial]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- "Postoperative intussusceptions in children and infants: a systematic review"
- [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- The abstract does not provide a structured summary.
- [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- "Postoperative intussusception (POI) is an unusual complication in children and infants who underwent various kinds of surgery. The early recognition was difficult for its rarity and atypical presentations. This study evaluates the clinical features of POI through a literature review."
- [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- The objectives are not explicitly stated.
- [No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- No information is provided about a review protocol or registration.
- [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- The eligibility criteria are not specified.
- [No]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
- "MEDLINE database was searched for relevant articles that reported the children and infants with POI since 1990 in English-language using the key word “postoperative intussusception”. All published studies containing clinical data for POI in children and infants were included. Reference lists of retrieved articles were reviewed for additional cases."
- [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- The full electronic search strategy is not provided.
- [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
- The process for selecting studies is not stated.
- [No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
- No information is provided about the method of data extraction or data confirmation.
- [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
- The data items are not listed or defined.
- [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
- No information is provided about the assessment of risk of bias.
- [No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
- No information is provided about the principal summary measures.
- [No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
- No information is provided about the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
- [No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
- The characteristics for each study are not presented.
- [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
- No information is provided about the risk of bias within studies.
- [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
- No information is provided about the results of individual studies.
- [No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
- Not applicable, as there is no meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
- The main findings are summarized, but the strength of evidence is not discussed.
- [No]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- The limitations are not discussed.
- [No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- A general interpretation of the results is provided, but implications for future research are not discussed.
- [No]

- No information is provided about the sources of funding or other support.
- [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and results.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "As surgical techniques have developed and the demand for procedures that cause less pain and have better cosmetic outcome, more and more surgeons draw their attention to minimally invasive techniques."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information is provided about a review protocol or registration.
[No] The existence of a review protocol and registration information is not mentioned.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Children with histologically confirmed acute appendicitis who received SILA or CLA were recruited."
[Yes] The study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "An electronic search was performed using EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE from 2000 to 2014."
[Yes] The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: No information is provided about the full electronic search strategy.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Children with histologically confirmed acute appendicitis who received SILA or CLA were recruited."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is stated.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies."
[Yes] The method of data extraction is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "The primary objective of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, length of hospital stay. Secondary objectives included an analysis of postoperative complications including wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, and ileus."
[Yes] The variables for which data were sought are listed and defined.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information is provided about the methods used for assessing risk of bias.
[No] The methods used for assessing risk of bias are not described.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: No information is provided about the principal summary measures.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No information is provided about the methods of handling data and combining results.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of data synthesis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No information is provided about the assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No information is provided about additional analyses.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: "The initial search strategy identified 213 citations and 26 of them were retrieved for full text review. Twelve trials met total inclusion criteria."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The 12 selected studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) included 2,109 participants."
[Yes] Characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information is provided about the risk of bias of each study.
[No] The risk of bias of each study is not presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Meta-analysis demonstrated no statistically significant in mean operating time for SILA compared with CLA. Meta-analysis demonstrated a statistically significant decrease in mean length of hospital stay for SILA compared with CLA."
[Yes] Simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates are provided.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No information is provided about the methods of handling data and combining results.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of data synthesis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information is provided about the assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No information is provided about additional analyses.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our study suggests that SILA is a feasible and safe surgical procedure alternative to CLA for pediatric patients with appendicitis."
[Yes] The main findings and the strength of evidence for each main outcome are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The overall methodologic quality and reporting of the included trials in children was poor."
[Yes] Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our study suggests that SILA is a feasible and safe surgical procedure alternative to CLA for pediatric patients with appendicitis."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No] The sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.

[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information is provided about the risk of bias of each study.
[No] The risk of bias of each study is not presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Meta-analysis demonstrated no statistically significant in mean operating time for SILA compared with CLA. Meta-analysis demonstrated a statistically significant decrease in mean length of hospital stay for SILA compared with CLA."
[Yes] Simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates are provided.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No information is provided about the methods of handling data and combining results.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of data synthesis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No information is provided about the assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of risk of bias across studies.

[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our study suggests that SILA is a feasible and safe surgical procedure alternative to CLA for pediatric patients with appendicitis."

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Minimally invasive surgery for congenital diaphragmatic hernia: a meta-analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To compare the safety and efficacy of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) with traditional open surgical approach for congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and study eligibility criteria.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a congenital defect in diaphragm development, which occurs in approximately 1 in 2500–4000 live births [1]. Surgical repair via laparotomy or thoracotomy is the traditional treatment for patients with CDH."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare the safety and efficacy of MIS with traditional surgical approach for CDH."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No relevant quote found.
[No] No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Studies that met all the following criteria were included in the meta-analysis: (1) the trial was a randomized or non-randomized clinical trial; (2) the study was designed to compare surgical outcomes of neonates with CDH between MIS intervention and open procedures; and (3) data on incidence of mortality, recurrence, patch use, and surgical complication rate were fully or partially reported."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A literature search was performed using the PubMed database, Embase, and the Cochrane central register of controlled trials using a defined set of criteria."
[Yes] The information sources for the literature search are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "We performed a literature search of the PubMed database (National Library of Medicine, Bethesda, MD, USA) that covered the period from 1966 to December 2013. The search conducted for Embase and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials was restricted to English-language literature."
[Yes] The full electronic search strategy for at least one database is presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two authors (Zhu and Wu) independently performed an electronic database search to identify studies that met the eligibility criteria."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "We extracted data from each eligible study, including general information, post-operative mortality, incidence of hernia recurrence, rates of patch use, and complications."
[Yes] The method of data extraction from reports is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: "We extracted data from each eligible study, including general information, post-operative mortality, incidence of hernia recurrence, rates of patch use, and complications."
[Yes] The variables for which data were sought are listed.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of assessing risk of bias in individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Dichotomous outcomes were expressed in relative risk (RR) with their 95 % confidence interval (CI) values."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of combining results of studies.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of assessing risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: "Our (Zhu and Wu) preliminary search revealed 70 relevant studies, and 61 of them were eventually excluded because they were merely narrative studies or case reports or did not evaluate the surgical outcomes that were the focus of this review."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All nine clinical trials [3–11] compared thoracoscopic or laparoscopic (only four laparoscopic cases) repair of CHD with open techniques. All the studies were non-randomized historical control trials."
[Yes] Characteristics for each study, including study size and design, are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of presenting risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Our meta-analysis revealed a significantly lower rate of post-operative death in the MIS group than in the open techniques group with an RR of 0.26 (95 % CI 0.10–0.68; p = 0.006) but a greater incidence of hernia recurrence with an RR of 3.42 (95 % CI 1.98–5.88; p < 0.00001). Rates of prosthetic patch use were similar between the two groups. Fewer cases of surgical complications were found in the MIS group with an RR of 0.66 (95 % CI 0.47–0.94; p = 0.02)."
[Yes] Simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of synthesis of results.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of assessing risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No relevant quote found.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no mention of additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "MIS for CDH repair is associated with lower post-operative mortality and morbidity compared with traditional open repair. Although rate of patch use appears to be comparable, the increased risk of CDH recurrence should not be ignored."
[Yes] The main findings, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome, are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "All the trials included are susceptible to the limitations of any retrospective review. They all have selection bias, and the numbers of patients are all small to draw a definitive conclusion."
[Yes] Limitations at study and outcome level, as well as review-level, are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "MIS for CDH repair is associated with lower post-operative mortality and morbidity compared with traditional open surgery. Although the rate of patch use appears to be comparable, the increased risk of recurrence of CDH should not be ignored. The lack of well-controlled prospective clinical trials might also be a reason for the inability to find significant predictive factors."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "YZ declares no conflict of interest. YW declares no conflict of interest. QP declares no conflict of interest. LM declares no conflict of interest. HL declares no conflict of interest. LL declares no conflict of interest."
[Yes] Sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are described.

Overall, 24 out of 27 PRISMA items were reported in the full text.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of paediatric bariatric surgery: a systematic review" - [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of surgical interventions to treat obese children and adolescents, and whether they are cost-effective." - [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "During the last two decades the prevalence of childhood and adolescent obesity has grown rapidly in most regions of the world." - [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This systematic review examines the evidence on effectiveness of surgical interventions to treat obese children and adolescents, and whether they are cost-effective." - [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported - [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up." - [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched PubMed, ISI Web of Science, Embase and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010, and hand-searched bibliographies." - [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported - [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included." - [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported - [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported - [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported - [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported - [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported - [No]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Thirty-seven articles were identified and included in the review." - [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Thirty-four relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years." - [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported - [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life were reported in the majority of studies." - [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) - [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported - [No]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Existing evidence suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life." - [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "This study was challenging due to a number of limitations in the existing literature." - [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Pending an improvement in the quality of available evidence, a cautious approach to child and adolescent bariatric surgery is warranted." - [Yes]
P27. Funding: "The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization." - [Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Laparoscopic-assisted anorectal pull-through for anorectal malformations: a systematic review and the need for standardization of outcome reporting"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this review was to evaluate worldwide experiences with LAARP with regard to indications, outcomes, and quality of reporting."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Laparoscopically assisted anorectal pull-through (LAARP) is becoming an increasingly common procedure to correct high and intermediate anorectal malformations (ARMs)."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study was to conduct a systematic review to evaluate the worldwide experience with LAARP with regard to indications, outcomes, and quality of reporting in published articles."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria were studies of ARMs, regardless of level of the defect, with or without associated anomalies, use of LAARP as a primary procedure or with colostomy, and studies reported after the year 2000."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the MEDLINE, PUBMED, and Cochrane databases (June 2000 to April 2008) was conducted."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "The initial search in the PUBMED database produced 24 articles, 11 of which met the inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "A data extraction form was created to standardize the collection of study elements from each included article."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported.
[NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The initial search in the PUBMED database produced 24 articles, 11 of which met the inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The studies included 124 patients (96 males, 28 females) with 80% reported as having high/intermediate malformations."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Reported outcomes included continence, rectal prolapse, the position of the rectum, manometry, contrast enema, postanal endosonography, and postoperative magnetic resonance imaging."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The number of studies dealing with LAARP is low. There is a need for both a standardization and improvement in the quality of reporting in LAARP research."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Our study has several limitations. First, this is a systematic review of mainly retrospective data. Second, because of the wide variation of reported outcomes, no formal meta-analysis and calculation of summary statistics could be performed."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "We conclude that there is an urgent need to increase the number of studies reporting LAARP-related outcomes. More efforts are needed by the pediatric surgery community to improve the quality of studies and standardization of reports related ARM."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

- The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We reviewed our experience and performed a systematic review of reports of EDT in pediatric patients." [Yes]
- The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and methods.

- The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

- The objectives are explicitly stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
[Yes] "Laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children: a meta-analysis"

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
[Yes] The introduction provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
[No] No information is provided about the existence of a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
[Yes] The methods specify the study characteristics (PICOS) and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
[Yes] The methods describe the information sources, including databases and the date last searched.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
[Yes] The methods state the process for selecting studies, including screening, eligibility, and inclusion in the systematic review.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
[Yes] The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
[Yes] The methods list and define the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
[Yes] The methods describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
[Yes] The methods state the principal summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
[Yes] The results give the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
[Yes] The results present characteristics for each study and provide the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
[Yes] The results present data on the risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates and confidence intervals.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and considers their relevance to key groups.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses limitations at the study and outcome level and at the review-level.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.

P1. Title: "Laparoscopic treatment of intussusception in children: A systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: No structured summary provided [No]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "There is still no agreement in pediatric surgery about safety and effectiveness of the use of minimally invasive surgery in this common pediatric condition." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "By reviewing available data we aimed to establish whether laparoscopy should be the primary technique in the surgical reduction of intussusception." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: No information provided [No]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "An online database search for all English language articles on pediatric small bowel obstruction, intussusception and laparoscopy in PubMed, Medline and Ovid from January 1990 to April 2012 was performed." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No full electronic search strategy provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Overall, 10 studies were identified which included a total of 276 cases of laparoscopically treated intussusception." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: No information provided [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: "The following variables were analyzed: age, laparoscopic success rate, reason for conversion, enterotomy rate, operative time, complications, and length of stay (LOS)." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No information provided [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Management of Recurrent Tracheoesophageal Fistulas: A Systematic Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal approach to the management of recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas (RTEF) is still in debate." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment." [Yes]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 23 papers between 1984 and 2012 described 57 patients undergoing some form of endoscopic treatment (ET) while 21 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 108 patients that underwent an open surgical repair." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "A total of 165 cases of RTEF are described and there were 44 (26.7%) cases associated with anastomotic leaks while 35 (21.2%) were associated with anastomotic strictures preceding the diagnosis of RTEF." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Of the 57 ET patients, there was an 84% success rate compared with 93.5% of 108 OS patients." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "OS for RTEF has a low morbidity and mortality, a higher success rate, and requires fewer treatments than an endoscopic repair." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The main limitations of this review include the heterogeneity of the included articles, particularly as case reports would predominantly report positive outcomes." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "OS for the repair of recurrent TEF has a low morbidity, mortality, and re-fistulation rate particularly when an interposition tissue is placed between the trachea and esophagus. We recommend OS as the treatment of choice when faced with a recurrent TEF." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "This review was conducted to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of this approach for a variety of different surgical indications in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of laparoscopic and open techniques in pediatric populations."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria: Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. Operative results reported for a “pediatric population”, using the words “children, infants or neonates” to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). Study subjects under 17 years of age only. Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques. Report on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned previously."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IgentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non–English language articles."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. Operative results reported for a “pediatric population”, using the words “children, infants or neonates” to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). Study subjects under 17 years of age only. Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques. Report on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned previously."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "16 appendectomy, 4 fundoplication and 4 inguinal hernia studies comparing procedural outcomes method were included."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "LOS was found to be significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of −1.44 days, although the OR time was significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of +12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6%). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignificantly increased compared to the open techniques."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no meta-analysis).
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the ‘newer’ MIS/laparoscopic technique."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and overall complication rates."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "Conflict of interest: None"
[Yes]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Surgical Management of Primary Severe Hypospadias in Children: Systematic 20-Year Review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We systematically reviewed the literature published during the last 20 years on the treatment of primary proximal hypospadias associated with severe ventral curvature." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The present systematic review shows the weak evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of the present review was to assess the results of studies published during the last 20 years on the primary repair of severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We included in this review only series containing detailed results after primary repair of severe hypospadias or after curvature correction in patients with primary severe hypospadias." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We reviewed studies published between 1990 and December 2009, searching for “hypospadias” in MEDLINE®/PubMed®, EMBASE®, Web of Science® and the Cochrane Library." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Three doctors reviewed the abstracts. Articles relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: Not reported [No]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P17. Results / Study selection: "We identified 69 studies for review." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: Not reported [No]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "We first reviewed the results of the different straightening procedures, then the crude complication rates (overall complication, fistula/dehiscence, stricture/stenosis rates) of the different urethroplasty techniques." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P23. Results / Additional analysis: <added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The present review illustrates that there is an extreme paucity of studies to address in an evidence-based manner many of the common issues related to the primary repair of proximal hypospadias." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "An important limitation is that this review did not account for some variables such as age at surgery, use of additional coverage of urethroplasty, and type of preoperative and postoperative drainage and care." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "This systematic review demonstrates the weak evidence supporting current management of primary severe hyposapdias." [Yes]
P27. Funding: Not reported [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Does Preputial Reconstruction Increase Complication Rate of Hypospadias Repair? 20-Year Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
[Yes] The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and key findings.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair."
[Yes] The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on PR during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of specific complications related to the procedure. Moreover, we performed a meta-analysis of studies comparing urethroplasty complications and reoperation rates in patients undergoing hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision."
[Yes] The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
[Yes] The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword 'hypospadias.'"
[Yes] The information sources and search strategy are described.

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[Yes] The process for selecting studies is described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
[Yes] The method of data extraction and any processes for obtaining and confirming data are not described.

P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported.
[NA] There is no specific mention of the data items sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of methods used for assessing risk of bias.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)."
[Yes] The principal summary measures are not stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of methods for handling data and combining results.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: "Twenty studies were identified."
[Yes] The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The 20 studies included 2215 patients undergoing preputial sparing hypospadias repair."
[Yes] Characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[NA] There is no presentation of data on risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "A meta-analysis of seven studies comparing patients undergoing PR vs. circumcision showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation associated with PR."
[Yes] Results of individual studies are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of methods for synthesizing results.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported.
[NA] There is no mention of additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
[Yes] The main findings and the strength of evidence are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Results of systematic reviews are unavoidably dependent on the criteria chosen to select the studies and the quality of the studies included."
[Yes] Limitations at study and review-level are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, but does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repair."
[Yes] A general interpretation of the results and implications for future research are provided.

P27. Funding: "The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest."
[Yes] Sources of funding and the role of funders are described.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Ideal timing of orchiopexy: a systematic review" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The ideal timing of orchiopexy for cryptorchidism has long been debated." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To assess the ideal timing for orchiopexy with respect to both fertility and malignancy outcomes." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We included all studies that examined the effect of age at orchiopexy on fertility or malignancy." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE, Embase, and CINAHL to find relevant articles." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two researchers independently performed each level of screening, comparing the selected studies to reach a consensus." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "One researcher extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second researcher checked the data for accuracy and completeness." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "We used the MINORS criteria to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies." [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [NA]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Our initial search yielded 198 studies. After screening, we quality assessed the 32 remaining studies that met our criteria." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Publication dates ranged from 1974 to 2011." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "We found one RCT that included fertility potential as an outcome which received a Jadad score of 3." [Yes]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis) [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses) [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age may optimize fertility potential and help protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The most direct measurement of male fertility is paternity rate and time until conception of a live born child, but these outcomes are difficult to assess." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Our study is the first step towards determining the ideal management of undescended testes." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "This research was carried out as part of the development of the Canadian Association of Pediatric Surgeons (CAPS) Evidence-Based Resource." [Yes]
