llm_message:
P1. Title: "Comparing the efficacy and safety between robotic-assisted versus open pyeloplasty in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This manuscript is mainly to systemically review the published reports that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic-assisted (RP) versus open pyeloplasty (OP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO)." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Open dismembered pyeloplasty remained the best standard treating children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO) despite the introduction of minimal invasive therapy." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This manuscript is mainly to systemically review the published reports that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic-assisted (RP) versus open pyeloplasty (OP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO)." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: "We used the following keywords: robotic, pyeloplasty, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, children, and pediatric." [Yes]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two authors (Hsu and Chang) of the current study independently searched and reviewed the articles." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors of this paper, Hsu and Chang, evaluated the quality of the study." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: Not reported [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported [No]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: Not reported [No]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "Initial research yielded 104 abstracts, and a total of 102 abstracts were included for evaluation after duplicates were removed." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included." [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Most studies reported median value of patient age, operative time, and hospital stay." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The included studies were all retrospective in origin with lack of prospective data." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty." [Yes]
P27. Funding: "The study is partly funded by Taipei Tzu Chi Hospital, Buddhist Tzu Chi Medical Foundation." [Yes]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
[No] The title does not clearly identify the report as a systematic review or meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
[No] The abstract does not provide a structured summary with all the required information.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
[Yes] The introduction provides an explicit statement of the objectives with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
[No] There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
[Yes] The methods specify the eligibility criteria used for study and report characteristics.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
[Yes] The methods describe the information sources used in the search.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
[No] The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
[Yes] The methods state the process for selecting studies.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
[Yes] The methods describe the method of data extraction and any processes for obtaining and confirming data.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
[Yes] The methods list and define the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
[Yes] The methods describe the methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
[Yes] The methods state the principal summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
[No] The results do not provide the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
[Yes] The results present characteristics for each study and provide the citations.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
[Yes] The results present data on risk of bias within studies.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
[Yes] The results present the results of individual studies.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[NA] Not applicable as there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
[NA] Not applicable as there is no assessment of risk of bias across studies.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
[NA] Not applicable as there are no additional analyses.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance to key groups.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
[Yes] The discussion discusses the limitations of the study.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
[Yes] The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
[No] There is no description of sources of funding or other support for the systematic review.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis. Intestinal rotational anomalies are frequent among patients with heterotaxy, but debate exists as to whether they are benign in nature, requiring careful observation alone, or if surgical correction is warranted to prevent obstruction or midgut volvulus."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "we undertook a systematic review of the available literature to determine (1) whether screening of IRA is obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy and (2) whether detection of a rotational anomaly warrant(s) surgical correction in such a fragile patient cohort."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies"
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, https://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. Finally, data regarding patients with heterotaxy from our own institution were also obtained."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies"
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: No specific mention of data extraction process.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items: No specific mention of variables sought or assumptions made.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: No mention of risk of bias assessment.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: No mention of principal summary measures.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted).
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted).
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "Nineteen studies met the eligibility criteria but reporting was adequate for 9."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "All studies were retrospective case series"
[Yes]

original_llm_message:
P1. Title: "Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis. Intestinal rotational anomalies are frequent among patients with heterotaxy, but debate exists as to whether they are benign in nature, requiring careful observation alone, or if surgical correction is warranted to prevent obstruction or midgut volvulus."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "we undertook a systematic review of the available literature to determine (1) whether screening of IRA is obligatory in “asymptomatic” patients with heterotaxy and (2) whether detection of a rotational anomaly warrant(s) surgical correction in such a fragile patient cohort."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies"
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, https://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. Finally, data regarding patients with heterotaxy from our own institution were also obtained."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). llm_message:
P1. Title: "Meta-analysis of robot-assisted vs conventional laparoscopic and open pyeloplasty in children" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "To critically analyse outcomes for robot-assisted pyeloplasty (RAP) vs conventional laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) or open pyeloplasty (OP) by systematic review and meta-analysis of published data." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "It remains largely unclear how the many technological enhancements offered by robot-assistance might translate into clinically measurable outcome benefits." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of the present study was therefore to undertake a meta-analysis of RAP vs LP and OP in children." [Yes]
P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No information provided [No]
P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Only comparative studies investigating RAP vs LP or OP in children were included." [Yes]
P7. Methods / Information sources: "Studies published up to December 2013 were identified from multiple literature databases." [Yes]
P8. Methods / Search: No information provided [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Two authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts, and assessed eligible articles against inclusion criteria." [Yes]
P11. Methods / Data items: No information provided [No]
P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "The methodological quality of studies was appraised using a star-based modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (mNOS)." [Yes]
P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Effect sizes were estimated by pooled odds ratios and weighted mean differences." [Yes]
P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No assessment of risk of bias across studies [NA]
P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P17. Results / Study selection: "In all, 12 studies met the inclusion criteria, involving 384 RAP, 131 LP, and 164 OP procedures." [Yes]
P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis" [Yes]
P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No information provided [No]
P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Pooled analyses determined no significant differences between RAP and LP or OP for all primary outcomes." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No meta-analysis performed [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No assessment of risk of bias across studies [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: No additional analyses performed [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Existing evidence shows largely comparable outcomes amongst surgical techniques available to treat pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction in children." [Yes]
P25. Discussion / Limitations: "No randomised controlled trials were identified." [Yes]
P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Higher quality evidence from prospective observational studies and clinical trials is required, as well as further cost-effectiveness analyses." [Yes]
P27. Funding: No information provided [No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents" - [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: No relevant quote found - [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Child and adolescent overweight and obesity have increased globally, and are associated with significant short and long term health consequences." - [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To assess the effects of surgical interventions for treating obesity in childhood and adolescence." - [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: No relevant quote found - [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: No relevant quote found - [No]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked. No language restrictions were applied." - [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "We searched the following sources on the 30th of March 2015 from inception to the specified database date and placed no restrictions on the language of publication." - [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "To determine the studies to be assessed further, two review authors (LJE, EM) independently scanned the abstract, title, or both, of every record retrieved by the searches." - [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "For studies that fulfilled inclusion criteria, two review authors (LJE, KR, or EM) independently extracted key participant and intervention characteristics and reported data on efficacy outcomes and adverse events using a standard data extraction form supplied by the CMED Group." - [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: No relevant quote found - [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "Two review authors (LJE, KR) independently assessed the risk of bias of each included study." - [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "For dichotomous outcomes we calculated odds ratio (OR) or risk ratio (RR) and corresponding 95% confidence interval (CI). For continuous outcomes we calculated the mean difference (MD) and corresponding 95% CI." - [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found - [No]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found - [No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: No relevant quote found - [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The initial search on 30 March 2015 identified 2405 records (2290 from database searches and 115 from trial registry searches); from these, 11 full text publications and protocols were identified for further examination and four trials met the inclusion criteria for ongoing studies." - [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: No relevant quote found - [No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: No relevant quote found - [No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The study authors reported a mean reduction in weight of 34.6 kg (95% confidence interval (CI) 30.2 to 39.0) at two years, representing a change in body mass index (BMI) of 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery intervention; and a mean reduction in weight of 3.0 kg (95% CI 2.1 to 8.1) representing a change in BMI of 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the lifestyle intervention." - [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: No relevant quote found - [No]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: No relevant quote found - [No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: No relevant quote found - [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Laparoscopic gastric banding led to greater body weight loss compared to a multi component lifestyle program in one small study with 50 patients." - [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The study authors reported a mean reduction in weight of 34.6 kg (95% confidence interval (CI) 30.2 to 39.0) at two years, representing a change in body mass index (BMI) of 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery intervention; and a mean reduction in weight of 3.0 kg (95% CI 2.1 to 8.1) representing a change in BMI of 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the lifestyle intervention." - [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "Laparoscopic gastric banding led to greater body weight loss compared to a multi component lifestyle program in one small study with 50 patients." - [Yes]

P27. Funding: No relevant quote found - [No]

P1. Title: "Laparoscopic versus open splenectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to compare the clinical outcomes between laparoscopic splenectomy and the traditional open splenectomy in children."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "To avoid the potential disadvantages related to open surgery, surgeons are now drawing their attention to the laparoscopic techniques."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "Clinical outcomes following LS and OS in children were pooled to provide results for comparison in this systematic review and meta-analysis."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Inclusion criteria: (1) clinical trials that compared laparoscopic versus open splenectomy between 1993 and 2015; (2) children under 18 years old who suffered from benign or malignant hematological diseases; exclusion criteria: (1) no open splenectomy as a control; (2) reports fewer than ten cases per group; and (3) studies did not provide available original data or duplicate publications."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "Published records were searched using the MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Web of Science from 1993 to 2015."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Studies comparing LS and OS in children were included regardless of randomization or non-randomization."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Included studies were independently reviewed by two reviewers, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "The primary outcome measures of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, blood loss, and length of postoperative stay. Secondary outcome measures included an analysis of the removal of accessory spleens and postoperative complications including postoperative high fever, acute chest syndrome (ACS), and ileus."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "For continuous data, we presented mean differences (MDs) with 95 % confidence intervals (CIs). For dichotomous data, we calculated odds ratios (ORs)."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not reported.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "21 of the 159 publications identified from the initial literature search were retrieved for full text review and 10 studies with 922 participants (508 received LS and 414 OS) met our total inclusion criteria."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "Tables 2 and 3 outlines the primary and secondary outcome results from each study."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Meta-analysis demonstrated that the LS approach had a significantly longer operative time than the OS approach with obvious statistical heterogeneity. Meta-analysis demonstrated a statistically significant decrease in blood loss for LS compared with OS while the statistical heterogeneity was evident. Meta-analysis revealed a statistically significant decrease in mean length of hospital stay for LS compared with OS. There was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in the removal of accessory spleens or postoperative complications including postoperative high fever, ACS, and ileus."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not reported.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our study suggests that LS is a feasible, safe, and effective surgical procedure alternative to OS for pediatric patients. LS is associated with shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and longer operative times compared with OS. Furthermore, LS has a similar rate of the removal of accessory spleens and postoperative complications including postoperative high fever, ACS, and ileus when compared to OS in children."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Our systematic review and meta-analysis have several limitations. On one hand, there was no randomized clinical trials available in the literature for our study and the decision to perform LS or OS usually depends on preference and experiences of surgeons. Besides, some of the included studies had rather small sample size. On the other hand, obvious statistical heterogeneity was detected among different trials in terms of operative time, blood loss, and length of hospital stay."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "LS is a feasible, safe, and effective surgical procedure alternative to OS for pediatric patients. LS is associated with shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and longer operative times compared with OS. Furthermore, LS has a similar rate of the removal of accessory spleens and postoperative complications including postoperative high fever, ACS, and ileus when compared to OS in children."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Open Versus Laparoscopic Inguinal Herniotomy in Children: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Focusing on Postoperative Complications"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "The aim of this study was to compare both of the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "There is an ongoing debate about whether laparoscopic or open herniorrhaphy (LH or OH) is the best choice for inguinal hernia in children."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "The aim of this study was to compare both of the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated, including the participants (children), interventions (laparoscopic or open herniorrhaphy), comparisons (operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications), outcomes, and study design (systematic review and meta-analysis).
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not reported.
Reasoning: There is no mention of a review protocol or registration information.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria included total available studies comparing LH with OH for the repair of PIH. The children were younger than 18 years when they underwent LH or OH."
Reasoning: The study characteristics (participants, interventions) and report characteristics (comparing LH with OH) used as eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "We systematically searched PubMed for relevant studies reported from 2005 to 2014 with the keywords 'laparoscopic herniorrhaphy', 'pediatric inguinal hernia,' and 'open herniorrhaphy.' Total reference lists of selected articles were also included."
Reasoning: The information sources (PubMed and reference lists) and the dates of coverage are described.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported.
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Two reviewers (S.F., Z.L.) screened the citation identified by the search strategy."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is stated, including screening and eligibility.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "The first author independently extracted data from the included studies."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Details of publication (type of repairing the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated."
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are listed (details of publication, inclusion and exclusion criteria, demographics).
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not reported.
Reasoning: There is no mention of methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "Weighted mean differences and odds ratios were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures used in the analysis are stated.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of combining results of studies or measures of consistency.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of additional analyses.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The initial search strategy identified 249 citations and 14 of them were retrieved for full-text review. Five trials met the total inclusion criteria and had no exclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are provided, along with reasons for exclusions.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The 5 selected trials included 553 participants. Two hundred and seventy-eight patients received OH and 275 received LH."
Reasoning: Characteristics for which data were extracted (number of participants, interventions) are presented.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not reported.
Reasoning: There is no presentation of data on risk of bias of each study.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "Compared with OH, shorter operative time for unilateral hernias was noted in extraperitoneal approaches’ group as well as for bilateral hernias. Besides, less total postoperative complications was found in LH group, especially for major postoperative complications in male children. However, no significant difference was observed between LH and OH in patients’ recurrence."
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each intervention group (operative time, postoperative complications) are presented.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of meta-analysis.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable.
Reasoning: This item is not applicable since there is no mention of additional analyses.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Our results show that LH is superior for the inguinal hernia repair in children, with shorter operative time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group as well as for bilateral hernias. Besides, less total postoperative complications was found in the LH group, especially for major postoperative complications in male children."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "Because of the limited number of patients and studies, more RCTs need to be conducted to confirm these findings; the learning curve in the 5 RCTs may play an underestimated role in the study, which may weaken the results of the comparison."
Reasoning: Limitations at study and outcome level (limited number of patients and studies, learning curve) and at review-level (weakened results) are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "LH can be accepted as the standard of care as long as total postoperative complications was substantially reduced, especially for major postoperative complications in male children."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Not reported.
Reasoning: There is no mention of sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
P1. Title: "[Yes] Residual aganglionosis after pull-through operation for Hirschsprung’s disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
- The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "[Yes] Most patients with Hirschsprung’s disease (HD) have a satisfactory outcome after pull-through (PT) operation. However, some children continue to have persistent bowel symptoms after the initial operation and may require redo PT. Redo PT operation in HD is usually indicated for anastomotic strictures or residual aganglionosis (RA). We designed this meta-analysis to determine the incidence and outcome of RA among patients with HD following PT operation."
- The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and study eligibility criteria.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "[Yes] Pull-through (PT) operations for Hirschsprung’s disease (HD) generally result in a satisfactory outcome. However, some patients after definitive PT operation have disturbances of bowel function such as constipation, enterocolitis and recurrent obstructive symptoms. In a few patients, persistent abdominal distension, constipation or enterocolitis is due to postoperative stricture or retained aganglionic segment which may require a redo PT operation. We designed this meta-analysis to determine the incidence and outcome of residual aganglionosis (RA) in patients with HD following PT operation."
- The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "[Yes] We designed this meta-analysis to determine the incidence and outcome of residual aganglionosis (RA) in patients with HD following PT operation."
- The objectives are explicitly stated.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: "[No]"
- No information is provided about a review protocol or registration.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "[Yes] PubMed® and MEDLINE® databases were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients with HD who had undergone redo PT operations for RA or transition-zone bowel (TZB) after initial operation between 1985 and 2011."
- The study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: "[Yes] PubMed® and MEDLINE® databases were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients with HD who had undergone redo PT operations for RA or transition-zone bowel (TZB) after initial operation between 1985 and 2011."
- The information sources are described.

P8. Methods / Search: "[No]"
- The full electronic search strategy is not presented.

P9. Methods / Study selection: "[Yes] Between 1985 and 2011, 29 published articles reported 555 patients with HD who underwent redo PT operation."
- The process for selecting studies is stated.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the method of data extraction.

P11. Methods / Data items: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the variables for which data were sought.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the methods used for assessing risk of bias.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the principal summary measures.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no additional analysis.

P17. Results / Study selection: "[Yes] Between 1985 and 2011, 29 published articles reported 555 patients with HD who underwent redo PT operation."
- The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "[Yes] Information about patient’s gender was reported in 135 (69.9%) patients. A male-to-female ratio of 3.5:1 was observed."
- Characteristics for which data were extracted are presented.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the risk of bias of each study.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "[Yes] Of the 134 patients, 99 (73.9%) patients had normal bowel habits after redo PT operation."
- Simple summary data for each intervention group are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no meta-analysis.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: "[NA]"
- Not applicable since there is no additional analysis.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "[Yes] Our meta-analysis reveals that RA and TZB are the underlying causes of persistent bowel symptoms in one-third of all patients requiring redo PT operation."
- The main findings are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "[Yes] Over the years, various PT operations have been used to treat patients with HD. It has been shown in several studies that there is no statistically significant difference in the functional outcome with respect to bowel function between the various PT procedures."
- Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "[Yes] The presence of RA or TZB means that resection of this section of bowel may cure the patients of their recurrent symptoms. Thus, a redo PT is generally recommended for surgical management of RA."
- A general interpretation of the results is provided.

P27. Funding: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "[Yes] Over the years, various PT operations have been used to treat patients with HD. It has been shown in several studies that there is no statistically significant difference in the functional outcome with respect to bowel function between the various PT procedures."
- Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "[Yes] The presence of RA or TZB means that resection of this section of bowel may cure the patients of their recurrent symptoms. Thus, a redo PT is generally recommended for surgical management of RA."
- A general interpretation of the results is provided.

P27. Funding: "[No]"
- No information is provided about the sources of funding for the systematic review.

llm_message:
P1. Title: "Delayed primary anastomosis for management of long-gap esophageal atresia: a meta-analysis of complications and long-term outcome"
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "This meta-analysis aimed to investigate the complications and long-term outcome in patients with LGEA managed by DPA."
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: "Management of newborns with long-gap esophageal atresia (LGEA) remains a challenge for pediatric surgeons."
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: "This meta-analysis aimed to investigate the complications and long-term outcome in patients with LGEA managed by DPA."
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Not applicable (no mention of a protocol or registration)
[NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "A systematic literature search was conducted for relevant articles published between 1981 and 2011."
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: "A systematic literature search was conducted for relevant articles published between 1981 and 2011."
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: "Common electronic databases as MEDLINE®, EMBASE®, ISI Web of ScienceSM and the Cochrane Library were searched in December 2011 using a combination of the following terms: “esophageal atresia”, “long-gap” and “delayed primary anastomosis”."
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: "Identified articles were reviewed by title, keywords and abstract by one of the authors (F.F.). All articles that did not contain original research data (e.g. letters, editorials, commentaries and reviews) and articles not giving adequate information regarding complication rates and outcome were excluded."
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: "An unblinded, standardized full-text assessment of relevant articles was independently performed by both authors (F.F. and P.P.). The data was extracted into an electronic datasheet in a standardized manner."
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: "Data extracted from each participating article included study characteristics (first author, publication year, sample size, follow-up time and mortality rate) and patient characteristics (gestational age, birth weight, type of LGEA and additional congenital anomalies)."
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not applicable (no mention of risk of bias assessment)
[NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: "The primary outcome of this analysis was complication rates."
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted)
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: "The literature search resulted in a total of 223 articles, of which 207 were identified by electronic database search and 16 by cross-referencing."
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: "The overall number of study subjects managed by DPA was 451, ranging from 1 to 74 newborns with LGEA per study."
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: "A cumulative meta-analysis revealed the incidences for each specific complication."
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The incidence for reported mortality rates was 34 out of 332 (95 % CI 7.3–14.1) patients."
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable (no meta-analysis conducted)
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable (no additional analyses conducted)
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "This meta-analysis shows that the DPA provides good long-term functional results."
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: "The potential risk of Barrett’s metaplasia highlights the need for continued long-term follow-up with regular endoscopic surveillance protocols."
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: "In conclusion, this meta-analysis shows that the DPA provides good long-term functional results."
[Yes]

P27. Funding: "The authors declare that they have no conflict of interests."
[Yes]

P1. Title: "Laparoscopic versus open orchiopexy for non-palpable undescended testes in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis" [Yes]
P2. Abstract / Structured summary: "Although shorter hospital stay is noted in LO, it does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT." [Yes]
P3. Introduction / Rationale: "The undescended testes (cryptorchidism) is one of the most common disorders of childhood, affecting 0.8–1.8% of infants at 1 year of age, 3% of full-term newborns, and 21% of premature babies." [Yes]
P4. Introduction / Objectives: "To compare the laparoscopic and open approaches, and did not find significant advantages of laparoscopy in the management of children with NPT." [Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: "Eligibility criteria included all available studies comparing LO with OO for the treatment of NPT in children." [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Not reported [No]
P9. Methods / Study selection: "Out of 226 studies, 2 RCTs and 5 OCSs were eligible for inclusion criteria." [Yes]
P10. Methods / Data collection process: "Three reviewers independently assessed selected studies, extracted and tabulated data from each article." [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: "The hospital stay of LO was significantly shorter than that of OO." [Yes]
P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable [NA]
P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable [NA]
P23. Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable [NA]
P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: "Although shorter hospital stay is noted in LO, it does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT." [Yes]
